newsitem.title: JAPAN: M'bishi Materials develops smog-eating concrete.
newsitem.headline: M'bishi Materials develops smog-eating concrete.

text.p: Mitsubishi Materials Corp said on Monday it had developed concrete paving blocks that remove nitrogen oxide pollutants from the surrounding air.
The blocks' surface contains titanium oxide, a substance that, when hit by sunlight, undergoes a catalytic reaction that removes nitrogen oxides from the air around it, the company said.
It also cited experiments showing that the concrete blocks removed 80 percent of the nitrogen oxides from the air when tested in a container in a laboratory.
The company said 50 square metres of the paving blocks have been installed on sidewalks along a highway in Osaka Prefecture in western Japan as an experiment to evaluate the material.
A unit of the company will begin the manufacture and sale of the concrete blocks in January, utilising a network of franchise operations that includes 18 firms.
The blocks will sell for 12,000 yen per cubic metre, about the same price as high-end paving blocks, the company said.
The company is also studying other potential uses of the technology, such as concrete sound barriers used along major highways.

The company said the pollutant-absorbing properties of the concrete would be long-lasting, as the small quantities of nitric acid that build up on the surface when nitrogen oxides are absorbed would be washed away by rainwater.
